author: m.kalinin
content:
> My gut feeling is that while importing pretty large blocks chain (say several epochs +) validating just block signatures shouldn't mitigate security too much. Going further it could be sufficient to validate just a random subset of blocks (like it is done in Eth1 Fast sync: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/1889).
With assumption that proposers are randomly elected and that honest proposer never signs off on the incorrect block, the following could be used to evaluate a number of blocks required to be tested. Suppose a half of validators are malicious then `p = 0.5 ** N`, where `p` is the probability of `N` blocks produced by malicious validators. For instance, with `N = 1000` the probability is `9e-302`. 

In other words, verifying proposer signatures of a thousand blocks that are randomly sampled is enough to say whether chain is valid or not, even if half of validators are malicious. Am I missing anything?

author: paulhauner
content:
> With assumption that proposers are randomly elected and that honest proposer never signs off on the incorrect block, the following could be used to evaluate a number of blocks required to be tested. Suppose a half of validators are malicious then `p = 0.5 ** N`, where `p` is the probability of `N` blocks produced by malicious validators. For instance, with `N = 1000` the probability is `9e-302`. 
> 
> In other words, verifying proposer signatures of a thousand blocks that are randomly sampled is enough to say whether chain is valid or not, even if half of validators are malicious. Am I missing anything?
<@!425572898787426305> I think this becomes a little more complicated if you assume that you're eclipsed. Say that I own 20% of validators and I eclipse you. I can provide a chain where I just skip the slots that I'm not producing. In those blocks that I produce I can arbitrarily eject other validators since the slashing signatures are not being checked. With this I can begin to increase my share of the validator set. Once I have ~50%, I can start owning eth1 voting and then begin to induct validators at will.

author: m.kalinin
content:
That's a very good point <@!361447803194441738>. If you own 20% of validator set at some point you could exploit inactivity leak and build your own alternative chain. When the canonical chain observes the alternative one it will slash validators if their votes are in the weak subjectivity period. But if you're eclipsed you won't see those slashings.

To be sure that the checkpoint you're chasing is the canonical one, you need to be sure that it's been finazlied by the canonical set of validators. If you observe two alternative checkpoints you may look for slashing messages to decide which one to follow. But if you're eclipsed you could be eclipsed with valid chain which is not the canonical one.

What do you think about requesting the most recent finalized checkpoint out of band? I remember there was a discussion related to weak subjectivity period, it was about requesting a root at the weak subjectivity period out of band to initiate the sync. Probably, we could request finalized head as well? It seems that those participants that have been online for a reasonably long time can make a much better justification about the canonical chain.

author: m.kalinin
content: There could be a decentralized service that provides this information out of band. Akin to discovery bootstrap nodes there could be sync bootstrap nodes supported by authorities. When the number of such nodes would be reasonably big we could even say that this service is BFT.

author: protolambda
content: <@615242182407880713> the deposit queue can be retrieved from reading deposit contract even logs from an eth1 RPC. Then compare the processing status against the eth1data and deposit index in the latest beacon state. Clients can expose an API to read that state, or you have to get a state from some other source. Rumor is a networking shell to act like a client, and requests blocks. There's no direct state request yet, you have to process blocks yourself if you don't want to use a client.
